heading: 2.1 Examples of H0 and H1

chapter: 2 Alpha and Beta in Hypothesis Testing
heading: 2.2 Definitions of Alpha and Beta
text: \(\alpha\) = probability Type error, known “false positive”\(\beta\) = probability Type II error, known “false negative”Accordingly,\(1-\alpha\) = “true negative,” .e., correctly rejecting null hypothesis\(1-\beta\) = “true positive,” .e., correctly rejecting null hypothesisNote , \(1-\beta\) another name, called power, statistical power.

chapter: 2 Alpha and Beta in Hypothesis Testing
heading: 2.3 Common Values of Alpha and Beta
text: Alpha (\(\alpha\)): Common choices \(\alpha\) 0.05, 0.01, 0.10. 5% significance level (\(\alpha\) = 0.05) frequently used many fields.commonly used power level (\(1-\beta\)) 0.80, meaning want 80% chance correctly rejecting false null hypothesis.

chapter: 3 The Meaning of Cohen’s d
heading: 3.1.2 Cohen’s d
text: \[d = \frac{m_2 -m_1}{s_{pooled}}=\frac{m_2 -m_1}{\sqrt{\frac{s_1^2+s_2^2}{2}}}=\frac{5}{15.81}=0.32\]Thus, sole distinction Cohen  mean difference lies consideration standard deviation.

chapter: 3 The Meaning of Cohen’s d
heading: 3.2.2 Cohen’s d > 1
text: Cohen d can greater 1, pooled standard deviation smaller mean difference.\[d = \frac{m_2 -m_1}{s_{pooled}}=\frac{m_2 -m_1}{\sqrt{\frac{s_1^2+s_2^2}{2}}}=\frac{5}{1.58}=3.16\]

chapter: 3 The Meaning of Cohen’s d
heading: 3.3 Data Examples

chapter: 3 The Meaning of Cohen’s d
heading: 3.3.1 Mean difference = 5 and SD = 1.58:
code:
# Set the seed for reproducibility
set.seed(123)

# Specify parameters
n1 <- 100  # Sample size for group 1
n2 <- 100  # Sample size for group 2
mean_diff <- 5  # Desired mean difference between groups
sd <- 1.58  # Common standard deviation for both groups

# Generate random samples for two groups
group1 <- rnorm(n1, mean = 0, sd = sd)
group2 <- rnorm(n2, mean = mean_diff, sd = sd)

# Perform a two-sample t-test
t.test(group1, group2)## 
##  Welch Two Sample t-test
## 
## data:  group1 and group2
## t = -22.309, df = 197.35, p-value < 2.2e-16
## alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0
## 95 percent confidence interval:
##  -5.101572 -4.272897
## sample estimates:
## mean of x mean of y 
## 0.1428413 4.8300761

text: Effect size quantifies strength relationship variables magnitude difference groups.

chapter: 4 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r
heading: 4.1 Definitions

chapter: 4 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r
heading: 4.1.1 Cohen’s d
text: Cohen’s d used quantify size difference two groups, taking account variability within group.\[d = \frac{m_2 -m_1}{s_{pooled}}=\frac{m_2 -m_1}{\sqrt{\frac{s_1^2+s_2^2}{2}}}\]\(s_1\) sample standard deviation group 1, whereas \(s_2\) sample standard deviation group 2.

chapter: 4 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r
heading: 4.1.2 Pearson r
text: Pearson product-moment correlation coefficient, often referred Pearson correlation coefficient, quantifies strength linear relationship two variables.\[r_{xy} =\frac{cov(x,y)}{s_xs_y}=\frac{\sum_{=1}^n (x_i-\bar{x})(y_i-\bar{y})}{\sqrt{\sum_{=1}^n (x_i-\bar{x})^2}\sqrt{\sum_{=1}^n (y_i-\bar{y})^2}}\]

chapter: 4 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r

chapter: 4 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r

text: Cohen’s d can assume values ranging 0 infinity (.e., can greater 1), whereas Pearson’s r confined range -1 1.Note , based best understanding (sure), Cohen’s d can negative well, depending define \(m_1\) \(m_2\) order put .

chapter: 4 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r

chapter: 4 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r
heading: 4.2.1 Convert r to d

chapter: 4 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r
heading: 4.2.2 Convert d to r
text: \[r=\frac{d}{\sqrt{4+d^2}}\]According Cohen, sometimes, people might want think effect sizes mean differences d terms r. Thus, can convert d r needed.instance, group 1 group 2 two experimental manipulations. effect size typically d. can convert r.provide data demonstrate connection d r.

chapter: 4 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r
heading: 4.2.3 Simulate both X and Y that are numerical
text: create column dichotomized x based mean x.
code:
# set the seed for reproducibility
set.seed(123)

# specify marginal means and standard deviations
mean_x <- 5
mean_y <- 6
sd_x <- 12
sd_y<- 14

## specify coefficient, which must be between -1 and 1
corcoef <- 0.5

## covariance between two variables
covariance <- corcoef * sd_x * sd_y

## variance-covariance matrix
sigma <- matrix(c(sd_x^2, covariance, covariance, sd_y^2), nrow = 2)

xy <- MASS::mvrnorm(n = 50, mu = c(mean_x, mean_y), Sigma = sigma)
colnames(xy) <- c("x", "y")
df <- data.frame(xy)
head(df)##           x          y
## 1 -2.188776  0.1167428
## 2  3.014416  2.8711033
## 3 20.168055 25.9184510
## 4 -4.307292 14.2689957
## 5  7.878421  6.4575243
## 6 10.288163 36.3225845
# plot it
plot(df)
abline(lm(y ~ x,data=df), col = "red")
cor.test(df$x,df$y)## 
##  Pearson's product-moment correlation
## 
## data:  df$x and df$y
## t = 4.2497, df = 48, p-value = 9.8e-05
## alternative hypothesis: true correlation is not equal to 0
## 95 percent confidence interval:
##  0.2861663 0.6994209
## sample estimates:
##       cor 
## 0.5228658
# dichotomize x
df$dichotomized_x<- ifelse(df$x >mean(df$x), 1, 0)
head(df)##           x          y dichotomized_x
## 1 -2.188776  0.1167428              0
## 2  3.014416  2.8711033              0
## 3 20.168055 25.9184510              1
## 4 -4.307292 14.2689957              0
## 5  7.878421  6.4575243              1
## 6 10.288163 36.3225845              1

chapter: 4 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r
heading: 4.2.4 Method 1: Direct Calculating d
text: Since got column dichotomized x, can actually use formula mentioned calculate Cohen’s d. , calculate means groups 1 2. , calculate sample standard deviations.\[d = \frac{m_2 -m_1}{s_{pooled}}=\frac{m_2 -m_1}{\sqrt{\frac{s_1^2+s_2^2}{2}}}\]
code:
# calculate group means
means<-aggregate(df$y, list(df$dichotomized_x), FUN=mean) 

# calculate sample standard deviation - pooled 
variances<- aggregate(df$y, list(df$dichotomized_x),FUN=var)
s_pooled=sqrt((variances$x[1]+variances$x[2])/2)

d_calculated<-(means$x[2]-means$x[1])/s_pooled
print(d_calculated)## [1] 1.252203

chapter: 4 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r
heading: 4.2.5 Method 2: Converting r to d
code:
# check the correlation coefficient
cor_result<-cor.test(df$x,df$y)
correlation_coefficient<-cor_result$estimate
d_converted<-2*correlation_coefficient/sqrt(1-(correlation_coefficient^2))
print(d_converted)##      cor 
## 1.226787

heading: 5.2 Sample Size
text: Sample size refers number observations individuals measured included study.

chapter: 5 How Effect Size, Sample Size, and Power Interact with Each Other
heading: 5.3 Statistical Power
text: \(1-\beta\) also called power, statistical power. probability , null hypothesis false correctly reject null hypothesis.

chapter: 5 How Effect Size, Sample Size, and Power Interact with Each Other
heading: 5.4 Keeping effect size the same: Effect of Sample Size on Power
text: : given effect size, sample size increases, power also increases.
code:
library(pwr)

## Sample Size = 100
result_100<-pwr.t.test(n=50,
           d = 0.5,
           sig.level = 0.05, 
           power = NULL, 
           type = "two.sample",
           alternative="two.sided")

## Sample Size = 140
result_140<-pwr.t.test(n=70,
           d = 0.5,
           sig.level = 0.05, 
           power = NULL, 
           type = "two.sample",
           alternative="two.sided")
## Sample Size = 100
plot(result_100)
## Sample Size = 140
plot(result_140)

chapter: 5 How Effect Size, Sample Size, and Power Interact with Each Other
heading: 5.5 Keeping power the same: Impact of Effect Size on Needed Sample Size
text: : given power, effect size increases, needed sample size decreases.
code:
library(pwr)

## Effect Size = 0.5
result_0_5<-pwr.t.test(n=NULL,
           d = 0.5,
           sig.level = 0.05, 
           power = 0.8, 
           type = "two.sample",
           alternative="two.sided")

## Effect Size = 0.8
result_0_8<-pwr.t.test(n=NULL,
           d = 0.8,
           sig.level = 0.05, 
           power = 0.8, 
           type = "two.sample",
           alternative="two.sided")
## Effect Size = 0.5
plot(result_0_5)
## Effect Size = 0.8
plot(result_0_8)

chapter: 5 How Effect Size, Sample Size, and Power Interact with Each Other
heading: 5.6 Keeping sample size the same: Impact of Effect Size on Power
text: : given sample size, effect size increases, power also increases.
code:
library(pwr)

## Effect Size = 0.5
result_0_5<-pwr.t.test(n=50,
           d = 0.5,
           sig.level = 0.05, 
           power = NULL, 
           type = "two.sample",
           alternative="two.sided")

## Effect Size = 0.8
result_0_8<-pwr.t.test(n=50,
           d = 0.8,
           sig.level = 0.05, 
           power = NULL, 
           type = "two.sample",
           alternative="two.sided")
## Effect Size = 0.5
plot(result_0_5)
## Effect Size = 0.8
plot(result_0_8)
